snippet: A domestic dispute was the backdrop for a Supreme Court case that asked whether a law implementing a treaty must be authorized by Congress.
abstract: Case involving Pennsylvania domestic dispute provides unlikely backdrop for Supreme Court justices in deciding whether a law implementing a treaty must be authorized by one of the powers granted to Congress by the Constitution; majority of justices seem inclined to impose limits on Congress's ability to enact such laws when they concern matters ordinarily left to states.
lead_paragraph: A domestic dispute was the backdrop for a Supreme Court case that asked whether a law implementing a treaty must be authorized by Congress.

headline.main: Domestic Dispute Leads to Test of Federal Power
headline.print_headline: Domestic Dispute Leads To Test of Federal Power
